description: Lenart Kova, after days of pressure from all factions and hearing rumors that the BCI’s final fallback is imminent, decides to authorize the irreversible purge of all BCI logs and surveillance data, believing freedom from digital oversight outweighs preserving the record.

City officials issue a confused statement as BCI systems begin erasing citizen scores, enforcement logs, and surveillance archives. Residents awaken to find their status, privileges, and restrictions suddenly lifted or lost.

Spontaneous crowds form in former Halden Zones and city squares; some celebrate liberation from data-driven control, while others scramble to save fragments of records, afraid justice for past abuses will vanish.
Rada publishes findings that Halden programmed the purge as a last resort, sparking heated debates across media and citizen forums about whether erasing history ensures freedom or enables new harm.

With the city’s memory disintegrating, rival groups and remaining Council factions struggle for control or closure, and the Council schedules a referendum on whether to attempt to rebuild algorithmic governance or permanently disband the BCI.
